frameDefinitions: A State_of_affairs is generally, or with regard to a particular Feature, representative of its class, which may be narrowed to a specific Comparison_set.
A Believer has faith in a piece of Content or an Element  which fits into a religious belief system made up of many articles of faith.
A Cognizer makes a judgment about an Evaluee.
A Cognizer has a Judgment of an Evaluee, expressing how high or low their regard for the Evaluee is.
A Container  is in a state of fullness/emptiness with respect to some Contents.
The words in this frame describe an Experiencer's emotions with respect to some Content.
frameExamples: The Elan truly is an <t>unusual</t> car; the first and only Lotus with a front engined/front wheel drive layout, and the first new Lotus to be introduced since 1975.
Do Muslims <t>believe</t> in the virgin birth of Jesus?
JUDGMENT:  She <t>admired</t> Einstein for his character.
What do you <t>think</t> of him as a linguist?
John carried a bucket <t>full</t> of water.
My <t>enjoyment</t> of the movie was considerably impaired by the seven-foot guy sitting in front of me.
listRoleDefinitions: The state of affairs which is evaluated with regard to whether it exhibits the essential characteristics of a Comparison_set.
A property of the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> wherein it differs or is similar to members of a <fen>Comparison_set</fen>.
The <fen>Believer</fen> is the person whose religious beliefs are in question.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Believer</fen>'s religious conviction. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a finite clause or in a in-PP Complement.
<fen>Role</fen> is a  function that an Element of the faith is believed to serve.
A predefined, fixed idea to which reference is made throughout the belief system.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the judgment. This role is typically expressed as the External Argument (or in a <ment>by</ment>-PP in passives).
Evaluee is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment is made. With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the Judge's judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP, e.g.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the one that makes a <fen>Judgment</fen>. This role is typically expressed as the External Argument (or in a <ment>by</ment>-PP in passives).
<fen>Evaluee</fen> is the person or thing that a judgment is made with respect to. With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
A description (from the point of view of the <fen>Cognizer</fen>) of the position of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> on a scale of approval.
<fen>Container</fen> is used for the entity whose fullness is being described.
<fen>Contents</fen> is used for the stuff that is present/absent in the <fen>Container</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Container</fen> is full.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> experiences the emotion or other internal state.

<fen>Content</fen> is what the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s feelings or experiences are directed towards or based upon.  The <fen>Content</fen> differs from a stimulus because the <fen>Content</fen> is not construed as being direcly responsible for causing the emotion.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflect his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the area about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has the particular experience.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The time at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is in the specified emotional state.
listRoleExamples: However I have always loved having an unusual <fex>name</fex> and I think it's a beautiful name. .
David Hasselhoff's daughters are normal <fex>in every way</fex>.
A Christian believes <fex>that Jesus of Nazareth was a prophet</fex>.
If a person believes in Jesus <fex>as his Saviour</fex>, he can he baptized.
I believe <fex>in Jesus</fex>
<fex>The boss</fex> appreciates you for your diligence.
The boss appreciates <fex>you</fex> for your diligence.
I admire you <fex>for your intellect</fex>.
She viewed him with an appreciative <fex>gaze</fex>.
<fex>The boss</fex> appreciates you for your diligence.
He regarded <fex>her</fex> poorly.
I hold him in the <fex>highest</fex> esteem.
John carried an empty <fex>bucket</fex>.
The bucket is  full <fex>of water</fex>.
Everyone loves <fex>compliments</fex>.
The delight <fex>on her face</fex> was mixed with asonishment.
Mr. Whiskers was upset <fex>about his cat treats</fex>.
Tracy was in an irritated <fex>mood</fex>.
It felt pretty awkward to partake in such a nervous <fex>ceremony</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex>, Bob was still interested in the young Republicans.
